alt_statements.statement: As someone who’s spent a career in public education and believes in the common good, I think tech companies should be held to a standard similar to schools: they must be transparent, protect those who are most vulnerable, and never treat people as products without their informed consent. User data should be collected minimally, clearly explained in plain language, and used in ways that genuinely serve individuals and communities, not just corporate profit—ideally with strong public oversight and meaningful consequences when companies cross the line.

As someone who spends her days teaching teenagers to think critically and ethically, I believe tech companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and honest about how they collect and use our data. At a minimum, they should obtain clear, informed consent, limit data collection to what’s truly necessary, and be held accountable when they misuse or fail to protect it. Our personal information shouldn’t be treated as an unlimited resource to exploit, but as something that belongs to individuals and communities, deserving of strong legal safeguards.

As someone who’s worked with wiring and safety codes my whole life, I think tech companies should be held to strict, commonsense standards when it comes to collecting and selling our data—clear rules, no fine-print tricks, and real accountability when they mess up. I don’t mind companies making an honest profit, but users should know exactly what’s being collected, have the option to opt out, and be confident that their information is locked down like a well-built electrical system, not left hanging loose for anyone to grab.

As someone who works in a service industry where trust is everything, I think tech companies should be held to a higher standard when it comes to user data: they should clearly explain what they collect, why they collect it, and give people real, easy control over whether their data is used or sold. Data about our habits, health, and beliefs is deeply personal, and treating it like a commodity without meaningful consent feels exploitative and undemocratic. I’m not against tech innovation or using data to improve services, but that has to come with strong privacy protections, strict regulation, and serious penalties when companies abuse that power.

As someone who spends a lot of time online tracking bird migrations and using apps on the trail, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and honest about what data they collect and how they profit from it. Users should have clear, simple options to opt out of data sharing and to delete their information, not just pages of fine print nobody can realistically parse. I’m not against companies making money, but they shouldn’t treat our personal lives like open season—basic respect, consent, and strong privacy protections ought to be the standard, not an afterthought.

As someone who runs a nonprofit and thinks a lot about power and accountability, I believe tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data less like a commodity and more like a public trust. At minimum, they should collect only what’s truly necessary, be radically transparent about how it’s used, and give people real, user-friendly control over their information—not buried in legalese. Monetizing data shouldn’t be allowed to undermine civil rights or deepen inequities, so there needs to be strong regulation, independent oversight, and meaningful consequences when companies abuse that trust.

As someone who makes a living sifting through evidence and fine print, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat user data like a serious liability, not a limitless asset. They should be required to explain clearly—without legalese—what they’re collecting, how it’s being used, and who it’s being sold or shared with, and users should have real control to opt out without being punished by a worse product. There also need to be strict legal limits on secondary uses of data (like profiling for insurance, employment, or credit) and meaningful penalties when companies are deceptive or negligent with people’s information. In a world where data can quietly shape people’s financial and personal lives, basic transparency and accountability shouldn’t be optional or buried in a 40-page terms-of-service.

As a medical research scientist, I’m acutely aware of how sensitive data can be and how easily it can be misused, so I believe tech companies have an ethical obligation to treat user data more like protected health information than a free commodity. From both a scientific and Jewish ethical standpoint, respecting human dignity and preventing harm (pikuach nefesh) should come before profit, which means users must retain meaningful control over their data and the right to opt out without being penalized.

As someone who grew up long before the internet and now sees how much of our lives are tracked, I believe tech companies have a moral duty to treat user data with the same respect and care they’d give to something sacred. As someone who’s spent a lifetime in finance and understands how incentives can warp behavior, I believe tech companies should be held to strict, legally enforceable standards of data privacy and transparency. As someone who practically lives online for school and reading, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and honest about what data they collect and exactly how they profit from it. As someone who works in law enforcement and sees firsthand how important both public safety and civil liberties are, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and honest about what data they collect and how they profit from it. As someone who values integrity, family, and personal responsibility, I believe tech companies have a moral duty to handle user data with honesty and transparency, clearly explaining what they collect and how they profit from it.
